Award.AwardTitle: Syzygies, Moduli Spaces, and Brill-Noether Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project concerns research in algebraic geometry, the study of polynomial equations. The investigator works on the connections between the algebraic properties of equations and the geometric properties of the spaces they define. In particular, this research project uses syzygies to study fundamental questions regarding Riemann surfaces, one of the most important classes of geometric objects. The investigation of syzygies, or the relations amongst equations, has long played a central role in algebra, with a history ranging from 19th-century invariant theory to 21st-century theoretical physics. Applications of this research include moduli spaces, matrix factorizations, string theory, enumerative geometry, and mirror symmetry.

In more detail, the investigator is working on relating the algebraic invariants associated to the extrinsic geometry of a Riemann surface embedded in projective space to its intrinsic geometry. The relevant algebraic invariants are the Betti numbers of the minimal free resolution of the coordinate ring, as defined by Hilbert, whereas the intrinsic geometry is encoded in the invariants of Brill-Noether theory. The investigator will explore longstanding fundamental conjectures predicting precise relationships between these invariants. The project investigates these conjectures and generalizations of them using several new techniques such as intersection theory, the moduli space of curves, Hurwitz space, and vector bundle techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project resulted in the completion of 5 papers, 4 of which have already been accepted or published. These papers are:

  • The Resolution of Paracanonical Curves of Odd Genus, joint with G. Farkas. Geometry and Topology (2018) 22 (7): 4235-4257.
  • Linear Syzygies of Curves with prescribed gonality, joint with G. Farkas. To appear in Advances in Math.
  • Projecting Syzygies of Curves. To appear in Algebraic Geometry.
  • Universal Secant Bundles and Syzygies of Canonical Curves. To appear in Inventiones Math. 
  • Betti Numbers of Curves and Multiple-Point Loci (preprint)

These papers lead to significant breakthroughs in the field, including the development of an important new technique of "universal secant bundles", appearing in the paper "Universal Secant Bundles and Syzygies of Canonical Curves" (to appear in Inventiones Math.). Collectively, the papers produced under this grant have led to a much improved understanding of the equations defining algebraic varieties, and led to the resolution of several important conjectures.

In terms of broader impacts, the research conducted by the PI has facilitated the development of computer algorithms to understand the geometry of varieties in terms of their algebraic properties. One of the questions coming up from the proposal was made the topic of a successful PhD student's thesis. The PI is actively engaged in the dissemination of mathematics, for instance by organizing the Algebra and Algebraic Geometry Seminar at University of Wisconsin-Madison. One important goal of this seminar is to promote the work of underrepresented groups. 


Last Modified: 10/07/2020
Modified by: Michael Kemeny
